head.title: WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters

article.h1: WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters

span.span:
David Dunlap Observatory, University of Toronto
P.O.Box 360, Richmond Hill, Ontario, Canada L4C 4Y6
e-mail: rucinski@astro.utoronto.ca

div.p: A sample of 86 contact binary systems in 14 globular clusters with available color index data in (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) or in (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) has been analyzed. A large fraction of all systems (at least one third) are numerous foreground Galactic Disk projections over long lines of sight to the clusters. Since the selection of the cluster members has been based on the MVâ¢(logâ¡P,câ¢oâ¢lâ¢oâ¢r)subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘Ÿitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P PUNCT:, italic-c italic-o italic-l italic-o italic-r CLOSE:)M_{V}(\log P,color) calibrations, the matter of a metallicity-correction required particular attention with the result that such a correction is apparently not needed at the present level of accuracy. Analysis of the color-magnitude and period-color relations shows that globular cluster members are under-luminous relative to the Galactic Disk contact systems mainly because of the smaller sizes and, consequently, shorter orbital periods; the color-index effect of the diminished blanketing is less important, especially for (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I). Among the Class-1 members (deviations in MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V} smaller than 0.5 mag.), the most common are Blue Straggler (BS) systems. The variability amplitudes for the BS systems show a significantly different distribution from that for systems below the Turn Off Point (TOP): The BS systems in the sample have only small amplitudes while the distribution for the systems below the TOP is peculiar in containing only large amplitude systems. This difference may be linked to the relatively small number of the detected Main Sequence contact systems below the TOP as resulting from an observational selection effect due to the rapidly increasing measurement difficulties below the TOP. As a consequence, efforts at determining the frequency of occurrence of the contact systems below the TOP have been judged to be premature, but the frequency among the BS stars could be moderately well established at about 45Â±10plus-or-minus4510NUMBER:45 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1045\pm 10 BS stars per one contact BS binary.

article.div: clusters: globular â€“ binaries: eclipsing â€“ blue stragglers

div.p: July 3, 2019

Our thinking about close binary stars in globular clusters (GCâ€™s) has undergone a tremendous change in the last decade. Once such binaries were thought to be totally absent in the GC environment, while now they appear to be of great importance to the dynamical evolution of the clusters. A large volume of research on the dynamical effects of the binary systems on the cluster evolution, including important and complex inter-relations with the evaporation and tidal-striping effects, has been summarized in several reviews starting with hut92 , with updates in Sections 9.5 and 9.6 of mh97 and in mcm98 . Solar-type contact binaries (also known as WÂ UMa-type variable stars) contain the least amounts of angular momentum that binary systems made of Main Sequence components can have. They represent last stages of the angular momentum loss (AML) evolution of primordial binaries or are one of the products of the dynamical inter-cluster interactions. Together with the RRÂ Lyr-type pulsating stars on the horizontal branch and SXÂ Phe-type pulsating stars among Blue Stragglers, the WÂ UMa-type binaries are the most common type of variables in the GCâ€™s.

The number of WÂ UMa-type binaries in GCâ€™s has expanded in the recent four years from 24 (mat96a ) to the current number of 86. This paper attempts to integrate and analyze the available data for these variables in order to establish most essential results and to guide further research. The analysis is similar in its goals to the study of the Galactic Disk systems which compared the WÂ UMa binaries in the galactic field â€“ as seen in the direction of the galactic Bulge in the OGLE survey â€“ with those in several old open clusters (open = R98). Searches for contact binaries in GCâ€™s are much more difficult than in open clusters. They require â€“ on top of a generous allocation of observing time permitting variability detection and monitoring over several nights â€“ at least moderate-size telescopes located in sites with excellent seeing. Cores of some clusters remain too compact for photometry of individual stars even in perfect seeing; such clusters must be observed with the Hubble Space Telescope for which continuous monitoring of variability over long periods of time is difficult to arrange. It is expected, however, that new methods of analysis of difference images, such as developed by ala98 and ala99 , will result in substantial progress in detection and analysis of variable stars in very dense fields close to the cores; one of the first applications to GCâ€™s (RRÂ Lyr stars in the core of M5) is by ole99 .

Because of the action of two possibly mutually reinforcing types of processes, of dynamical interactions and of the magnetic braking, rather than one â€“ as in the Galactic Disk and in open clusters, where only the latter mechanism would be sufficiently effective â€“ one may expect high frequency of occurrence of the contact systems in globular clusters, possibly even higher than in the Disk. It is, in fact, surprisingly high in the Disk: As shown in R98, the Disk systems show an increase in the frequency of occurrence among Fâ€“K dwarfs over time, in the accessible range of 0.7 â€“ 7 Gyr, reaching the spatial frequency as high as about one such binary (counted as one object) per 80 â€“ 100 single stars in the Galactic Disk. Contact systems with spectral types earlier than about middle A-type and orbital periods longer than 1.3 â€“ 1.5 days are less common with currently un-measurable frequency of occurrence, as shown in ogle3 ; this long-period cutoff may be a function of the parent population because the contact binaries with periods up to 2.5 â€“ 3 days are known to exists in LMC (macho ). The high frequency of contact binaries with a gradual increase with age in old open clusters is consistent with the prolonged magnetic-wind braking AML process acting over a time scale of some 1 â€“ 5 Gyr (R98) and producing relatively long-lived contact systems.

Contrary to expectations based on the above reasoning, the preliminary indications from individual studies that reported discoveries of contact binaries in GCâ€™s (and are cited in this paper) do not confirm the high frequency of occurrence in these clusters. As several authors of such papers already remarked â€“ but bearing in mind the tremendous technical difficulties â€“ the frequency appears to be relatively low, at the level of a small fraction of a percent and some clusters do not seem to have WÂ UMa-type binaries at all. An attempt to assess this matter is presented in this paper. It is argued that, at this moment, we cannot really say much about the frequency of occurrence of the contact systems on the Main Sequence, below the Turn-Off Point; however, the frequency among the Blue Stragglers appears to be high, some 2 to 3 times higher that among the stars of the Galactic Disk.

The current paper consists of a description of the sample of clusters with contact binaries in SectionÂ 2, then of the sample itself in SectionÂ 3. The observed metallicity effects affecting the absolute-magnitude calibration (which is used to select the members) and affecting the observed properties of the systems are described in SectionsÂ 4 and 5. The color-magnitude and the period-color relations are discussed in SectionsÂ 6 and 7. Details concerning systems with EB-type light curves, Blue Straggler contact systems and the frequency of occurrence are given in SectionsÂ 8 â€“ 10. Conclusions are stated in SectionÂ 11.

The sample of GCâ€™s surveyed deep enough to include Main Sequence stars, below the Turn-Off Point (TOP), currently consists of 14 clusters. The sample is quasi random in the sense that several authors contributed the data using their own preferences, but that practically all data have come from ground-based telescopes. Dr.Â KaÅ‚uÅ¼ny and his collaborators, who contributed most of the results, selected primarily the nearest clusters, with moderately developed cores (permitting photometry close to the centers) and avoiding those with small galactic latitudes, within |b|<10âˆ˜ğ‘superscript10VERTBAR:| italic-b VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end|b|<10^{\circ}. The essential parameters characterizing the clusters are given in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters, with clusters arranged according to the NGC number. To insure uniformity of these parameters, they have been taken from the database of har96 , version June 22, 1999, which is available at: http://physun.physics.mcmaster.ca/Globular.html. In TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters we give the following parameters: the galactic coordinates lğ‘™italic-ll, bğ‘italic-bb in degrees, the galacto-centric distance RGâ¢Csubscriptğ‘…ğºğ¶italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{GC} in kpc, the reddening EB-Vsubscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{B-V}, the observed distance modulus (m-M)Vsubscriptğ‘šğ‘€ğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:minus italic-M CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(m-M)_{V}, the metallicity parameter [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] and the concentration parameter cğ‘italic-cc (for collapsed cores, c=2.5ğ‘2.5italic-c RELOP:equals NUMBER:2.5c=2.5). The galacto-centric distances span a wide range 3.5<RGâ¢C<18.53.5subscriptğ‘…ğºğ¶18.5NUMBER:3.5 RELOP:less-than italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-G italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:18.53.5<R_{GC}<18.5 kpc while the metallicities occur within the representative range -2.22<[Fâ¢e/H]<-0.732.22delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»0.73ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.22 RELOP:less-than OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.73-2.22<[Fe/H]<-0.73. The sample is dominated by clusters with moderate and low concentration; clusters with câ†’2.5â†’ğ‘2.5italic-c ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:2.5c\rightarrow 2.5 are under-represented. Eight clusters have galactic latitude |b|<20âˆ˜ğ‘superscript20VERTBAR:| italic-b VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:20 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end|b|<20^{\circ} indicating a possibility of large interstellar extinction and heavy Milky Way stars contamination; for three clusters, NGCÂ 4372, NGCÂ 6121 and NGCÂ 6441, the reddening is large, EB-V>0.3subscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰0.3italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.3E_{B-V}>0.3.
The cluster sample requires some comments:

While TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters lists 14 clusters, the entry for NGC 5904 (M5) actually reports a null result because all the systems suggested as contact binaries by yr96 turned out to be spurious detections, as has been shown by kal99 . The cluster has been monitored for variability of its stars by several investigators (see references to TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters).

NGC 4372 is a very important cluster because of its low metallicity and a large number of systems discovered in its direction. Unfortunately, because of its low galactic altitude of b=-10âˆ˜ğ‘superscript10italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endb=-10^{\circ}, it is has a large and patchy reddening. The discovery paper by kk93 gives, in its TableÂ 3, the observed data in (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) and (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I), but the patchiness-corrected data are given only for the former color index. The corrections have been calculated for (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) assuming the relation Î”â¢EV-I=1.24â¢Î”â¢EB-V=1.24â¢[(B-V)c-(B-V)]Î”subscriptğ¸ğ‘‰ğ¼1.24Î”subscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰1.24delimited-[]subscriptğµğ‘‰ğ‘ğµğ‘‰Delta italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.24 Delta italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.24 OPEN:[ OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) CLOSE:]\Delta E_{V-I}=1.24\,\Delta E_{B-V}=1.24\,[(B-V)_{c}-(B-V)]. The same slope is used throughout this paper in deriving the values of EV-Isubscriptğ¸ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{V-I} from EB-Vsubscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endE_{B-V}. On top of the patchy reddening, the values of the mean reddening and of the distance modulus are very uncertain for this cluster. While KaÅ‚uÅ¼ny & Krzeminski assume EB-V=0.48subscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰0.48italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.48E_{B-V}=0.48 and (m-M)V=14.8subscriptğ‘šğ‘€ğ‘‰14.8OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:minus italic-M CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:14.8(m-M)_{V}=14.8, the Harris database (TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters here) quotes EB-V=0.39subscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰0.39italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.39E_{B-V}=0.39 and (m-M)V=15.01subscriptğ‘šğ‘€ğ‘‰15.01OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:minus italic-M CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:15.01(m-M)_{V}=15.01. For consistency, the Harris set has been used here, but â€“ as we discuss in the next Section â€“ this choice makes a very important difference in ascertaining membership of systems detected in this cluster.

The color-magnitude of the core of NGCÂ 6752 has been studied with the Hubble Space Telescope (rb97 ). It indicates a relatively high frequency of binary stars at a level of 15-381538NUMBER:15 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:3815-38 percent in the inner core, but below 16 percent beyond the core. The relative frequency must be therefore a strong function of the radial distance from the cluster center. Unfortunately, searches for variable stars in the clusters analyzed in this paper are not uniform in this respect: Some clusters were observed with the inclusion of the cores, some were observed only at some distance from the center where crowding was assumed to be tolerable. This casts a large uncertainty on any considerations involving numbers of contact systems and their frequency of occurrence relative to other stars.

All contact binary systems discovered in globular clusters are listed in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. The Fourier-analysis of the light curves was not used to verify the WÂ UMa-type or the EW shape of the light-curves (as in the selection of the OGLE sample in ogle1 ) because of the partial coverage of some of the light curves which could produce incorrect values of the Fourier coefficients; the general appearance of the light curve and the original classification by the discoverers were the only criteria used here. Contact systems with unequally deep eclipses (EB-type light curves) have been retained; they are marked as such in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. Systems having light curves suggesting detached components (EA type) are not considered here.

The empty entries in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters are due to the fact that most of the photometric searches have been done either in Bğµitalic-BB and Vğ‘‰italic-VV band-passes or Vğ‘‰italic-VV and ICsubscriptğ¼ğ¶italic-I POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:endI_{C} band-passes (the subscript indicating that the Iğ¼italic-II band is of the Cousins system will not be used from now on). Thus, the available data split in two sets, forcing us to discuss all relations and all properties in parallel in Vğ‘‰italic-VV and (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) and in Vğ‘‰italic-VV and (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I). We will call these the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV-set and the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI-set. Only one cluster was observed in all three bands, NGC 4372 (kk93 ) permitting consideration of two photometric indices, (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) and (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I), for 8 contact systems in this cluster. As luck would have it, this is the cluster which is the most heavily reddened with a highly patchy and uncertain extinction.

TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters lists the variables with the names and designations as assigned in the discovery papers. For each system, we give the orbital period in days, then the maximum brightness Vğ‘‰italic-VV, (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) and/or (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) and the total variability amplitude AVsubscriptğ´ğ‘‰italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endA_{V}. The last columns give our results on the membership to the parent clusters and the variability/membership type (see below). Assignment of the membership has been performed by comparison of â€œobservedâ€ absolute magnitudes, derived from the distance modulus: MVoâ¢bâ¢s=V-(m-M)Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ ğ‘‰subscriptğ‘šğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-V ADDOP:minus OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:minus italic-M CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{obs}=V-(m-M)_{V}, with those derived from the calibrations, MVBâ¢V=MVâ¢(logâ¡P,B-V)superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ƒğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P PUNCT:, italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)M_{V}^{BV}=M_{V}(\log P,B-V) or MVVâ¢I=MVâ¢(logâ¡P,V-I)superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ƒğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P PUNCT:, italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)M_{V}^{VI}=M_{V}(\log P,V-I), as described in more detail below. A simple criterion for membership was used calling systems with the deviations in Î”â¢MV=MVoâ¢bâ¢s-MVcâ¢aâ¢lÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V}=M_{V}^{obs}-M_{V}^{cal} smaller than 0.5 mag the ClassÂ 1 members and those with 0.5<|Î”â¢MV|<1.00.5Î”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰1.0NUMBER:0.5 RELOP:less-than VERTBAR:| Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end VERTBAR:| RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1.00.5<|\Delta M_{V}|<1.0 the ClassÂ 2 members (here MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} takes the meaning of MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} or MVVâ¢Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{VI} depending which one has been available). Deviations larger than one magnitude were assumed to signify that the binary is not a member but a foreground or background projection.
The calibrations used in this paper have been:

div.p: The MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} calibration is based on the Hipparcos data (rd97 ) while the one for MVVâ¢Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{VI} was developed and served well for the analysis of all the OGLE data (ogle1 , ogle2 , ogle3 , open ). No allowance for lowered metallicity of GCâ€™s in the calibration has been made. We discuss this important issue in the next SectionÂ 4.

The deviations Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} are shown in graphical form in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters versus the orbital period and color index, for both color-index sets. While many systems do fall within the band of Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} close to zero, a large fraction of systems are actually foreground projections onto the fields of the observed clusters. This fully agrees with the high frequency of the WÂ UMa-type binaries in the Galactic Disk. The data based on the (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) index show a somewhat better consistency, with smaller scatter in Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} and with a better definition of the group of the Class-1 members. This may be due to a weaker dependence of this index on the interstellar reddening and/or on the metallicity, but may possibly be simply due to lesser photometric difficulties of observing red stars in the Vğ‘‰italic-VV and Iğ¼italic-II bands than in the Bğµitalic-BB and Vğ‘‰italic-VV bands. As pointed out to the author by Dr.Â KaÅ‚uÅ¼ny (private communication), selection of the best photometric bands is not an easy matter so that (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) may not always be preferable to (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V): The upper MS is better observable in Bğµitalic-BB than in Iğ¼italic-II because the numerous red dwarfs from the lower MS produce a strong background in Iğ¼italic-II; the Iğ¼italic-II band is also inconvenient for red stars because Asymptotic Giant Branch stars are usually strongly over-exposed and prevent photometry of other stars close to cluster centers.

The two penultimate columns of TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters give the number of contact systems in the GCâ€™s. ndâ¢eâ¢tsubscriptğ‘›ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘¡italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d italic-e italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{det} is the total number of systems in a cluster, while nCâ¢1subscriptğ‘›ğ¶1italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{C1} and nCâ¢2subscriptğ‘›ğ¶2italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-C NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{C2} are the numbers of Class-1 and Class-2 members, respectively. nBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘›ğµğ‘†italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{BS} is the number of Blue Stragglers (of both classes). NBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘ğµğ‘†italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{BS} are very approximate estimates of Blue Stragglers which were monitored for variability in the GCâ€™s. We will discuss these data later, in SectionsÂ 9 and 10. The approximate locations of the color indices at the Turn-Off Point are marked by vertical broken lines in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. Note that practically all systems to the blue of these lines (i.e. the Blue Stragglers) are members of the clusters.

The cluster-member selection process described above assumes that the calibration formulae, Eq.Â 1 and Eq.Â 2 are applicable to contact systems in globular clusters. This is verified by assuming that most typical systems which have been detected in a given direction are actually genuine members of the clusters. In effect, we require that the calibrations reproduce the modal (most probable) values of the deviations Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V}. The histograms of the deviations are shown in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. Disregarding a complication of the metallicity-dependence of MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} which will be discussed in the next section, we can observe the following facts:
There are 35 Class-1 systems in the sample, that is roughly 1/2 of the total.

The number of the cluster members would increase by four if we add Class-2 systems which have blue color indices and short periods characteristic for PopulationÂ II Blue Straggler systems (SectionÂ 9).
We have no good argument to claim that any of the eight remaining Class-2 systems is a cluster member.
There are 21 definite non-members in the sample, that is about 1/3 of the total number. All but one are foreground Disk systems.

The only obvious background system is V6 in NGC 6752. The Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} deviation of about 2.5 mag.Â suggests that the system is some 3 times further away than the cluster, at a distant periphery of the Galaxy at the distance of some 15 kpc.

As discussed in kal98a , there exists an ambiguity with the orbital period for the only contact system detected in M3, V238. It appears that neither of the acceptable periods places the system in the cluster. The two possibilities are joined by a dotted line in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. Dr.Â KaÅ‚uÅ¼ny (private communication) suspects â€“ from analysis of the individual CCD images â€“ that blending with a red giant is the cause of photometric difficulties with V238.

section.h2: 4 Metallicity effects in the MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V} calibrations

div.p: The cluster-selection process requires a clear conceptual separation of the effects of lowered metallicity on the simplified MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V} calibrations given by Equations 1 and 2 (they are called here MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} or specified as MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} or MVVâ¢Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{VI}) which we use for selecting the cluster members from the effects genuinely influencing the observed binary properties, such as the absolute magnitudes MVoâ¢bâ¢ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{obs} (derived from cluster moduli), the de-reddened color indices or the orbital periods. Here we concentrate on the effects affecting MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} and solely from the observational point of view, without going into the details of how genuine properties are affected; this will be discussed in the next SectionÂ 5. We note that once we select a sample of the cluster members, we will discuss only the directly observed quantities; the values of MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} will not be used from this point at all.

In cal2 arguments have been presented that the MVcâ¢aâ¢l=MVâ¢(logâ¡P,color)superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ƒcoloritalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P PUNCT:, color CLOSE:)M_{V}^{cal}=M_{V}(\log P,{\rm color}) calibrations require small, but significant corrections for metallicity variations. The corrections would reflect the blue colors of PopulationÂ II stars which have low atmospheric blanketing due to weak spectral lines of metals. It was argued that while the period term in Equations 1 and 2 would account for any differences in the system size, the color-index term would require a correction as a proxy of the effective temperature. The data and the available calibrations were very preliminary at that time; the current material is much richer so that the need for the corrections can be re-evaluated. This matter is very closely linked to the selection of the cluster members, so that we must explain the details of this process.

FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters shows the same deviations Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} as in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters, but this time plotted versus [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] for the clusters. The slanting lines give the metallicity corrections Î´â¢MVBâ¢V=-0.3â¢[Fâ¢e/H]ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰0.3delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»italic-delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.3 OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:]\delta M_{V}^{BV}=-0.3\,[Fe/H] and Î´â¢MVVâ¢I=-0.12â¢[Fâ¢e/H]ğ›¿superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼0.12delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»italic-delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.12 OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:]\delta M_{V}^{VI}=-0.12\,[Fe/H], as suggested in cal2 . To visualize how the corrections would impact the membership selection process, the Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} deviations â€“ with the metallicity corrections applied â€“ are shown as broken-line histograms in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters.

FiguresÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters and WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters contain the only available information on the need of the corrections and how their use would influence the selection of the cluster members. The situation is relatively simple for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set: Because of the well-known low sensitivity of this color index to metallicity variations, the current data do not forcefully suggest or reject the need for the metallicity corrections, although the case of no corrections seems to be slightly preferable; for simplicity, we assume that they are not needed. The data for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV-set show a large scatter in the band of the expected members and its is difficult to decide if the corrections are really needed. The crucial clusters for resolution of the problem for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set are the two clusters with the lowest metallicities [Fâ¢e/H]<-2delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»2OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2[Fe/H]<-2, NGC 4372 and NGC 5466.

As remarked before, NGC 4372 is seen at low galactic latitude through a patchy interstellar extinction. However, the cluster was observed in Bâ¢Vâ¢Iğµğ‘‰ğ¼italic-B italic-V italic-IBVI so that two sets of color indices are available and a consistency check is in principle available. Assuming the data as in Harrisâ€™ database (as given in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters), the MVVâ¢Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{VI} calibration indicates that none of the contact systems can be classified as Class-1 member while the MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} calibration suggests that one system, V4, is a ClassÂ 1 member. However, if we follow the assumptions of kk93 , EB-V=0.48subscriptğ¸ğµğ‘‰0.48italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.48E_{B-V}=0.48 and (m-M)V=14.8subscriptğ‘šğ‘€ğ‘‰14.8OPEN:( italic-m ADDOP:minus italic-M CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:14.8(m-M)_{V}=14.8, then large shifts in Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} by 0.49 and 0.61 mag.Â for both color-index sets occur: While MVoâ¢bâ¢ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{obs} become fainter by +0.210.21ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.21+0.21 mag., the predicted MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} and MVVâ¢Isuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘‰ğ¼italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-V italic-I POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{VI} become brighter by -0.280.28ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.28-0.28 and -0.400.40ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.40-0.40 mag. As the result, all data points for this cluster slide down in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters by amounts shown there by arrows. While for the Harris data only the system V4 would be a Class-1 member in the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set (without a confirming evidence from the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set), now the systems V4, V16 and V22 would be Class-1 members for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set and V5, V16 and V22 would be Class-1 members for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set. One gains then in consistency between both sets for V16 and V22, but the matter of membership remains unclear for V4 and V5. It is obvious that only three or four systems among the eight might be members of NGCÂ 4372, but we cannot be absolutely sure which ones. In this situation, we have taken a conservative approach and conclude that the data for NGC 4372 are too uncertain to be sure of the membership of the systems in this cluster; this cluster cannot tell us much about the need for a metallicity correction in the calibration. We note that judging by its period-color combination, the system V22 is a genuine Blue Straggler and irrespectively how big is its deviation Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V}, it is almost certainly a member of NGCÂ 4372 (see SectionÂ 9).

NGC 5466, with even more extreme metallicity than that of NGCÂ 4372 of [Fâ¢e/H]=-2.22delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»2.22OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.22[Fe/H]=-2.22, follows the Hipparcos calibration for the Disk stars (rd97 ), without any metallicity correction, very well. The two contact binaries must be genuine members simply because at the galactic latitude of b=+74âˆ˜ğ‘superscript74italic-b RELOP:equals ADDOP:plus NUMBER:74 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:compose POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endb=+74^{\circ} chances of having Disk population stars within the cluster are practically equal to zero. Also, both stars are exceptionally blue, belonging to the Blue Straggler group of contact binaries (see SectionÂ 9); equally blue systems very rarely occur in the Galactic Disk.

Guided mostly by the case of NGC 5466 and by the resulting simplicity of the assumption, we conclude that the MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V} calibrations established for [Fâ¢e/H]=0delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»0OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:equals NUMBER:0[Fe/H]=0 apparently work well for low values of metallicity and that the [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H]-corrections in the expressions for MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} are apparently not needed. As we will see in the next sections, the color indices of the low-metallicity systems are definitely much bluer than those for Disk systems, so that â€“ without any corrections â€“ one would expect values of MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} indicating artificially higher luminosities. Since this is not observed, some other metallicity-dependent factor must provide a compensating effect through the period-term (this may be for example the un-accounted for influence of the mass-ratio). Concerning the previous, apparently erroneous result in cal2 , we remark here that the correction of -0.3Ã—[Fâ¢e/H]0.3delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.3 MULOP:times OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:]-0.3\times[Fe/H] for the (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V)-based calibration was suggested for an old version of the MVBâ¢Vsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğµğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{BV} calibration which has been superseded by the much better Hipparcos calibration. The corresponding correction for the (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I)-calibration of -0.12Ã—[Fâ¢e/H]0.12delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.12 MULOP:times OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:]-0.12\times[Fe/H] was suggested for consistency with the one for (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V), but it was always recognized that it was smaller than the measurement and definition uncertainty of the calibration itself.

In summarizing the main effects of lowered metallicity, we discuss two effects which manifest themselves very differently: of the blue atmospheres (for the same effective temperature) and of smaller stellar sizes.

The decreased metallicity influences the atmospheric structure in that metal lines produce less blanketing so that stars become bluer. Only this effect was discussed in cal2 , together with its possible influence onto the MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V} calibrations. For consistency with the previous results, we use the same relations between the color-index changes and [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] as evaluated from the models of bk92 . The expected changes in the color indices (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) and (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) are given for a MS star atmosphere at Teâ¢fâ¢f=5000subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“5000italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-f italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5000T_{eff}=5000Â K in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. Obviously, several qualifications may be in order here: Single-star model-atmosphere results may be in-applicable to magnetically active contact binaries and the color index data have been calculated for spherical stars whereas strong and variable limb darkening effects are always present in contact binaries.

The low-metallicity systems are expected to have smaller dimensions and â€“ for the same contact geometry as for Galactic Disk systems â€“ should have shorter periods than PopulationÂ I systems. In the currently sole study on properties of PopulationÂ II contact systems binaries by web79 , the stress was on the influence of the prolonged angular-momentum loss for such old objects. The author, however, remarked about the smaller sizes of such systems relative to PopulationÂ I systems, but did not discuss this point any further. Some guidance on the expected effect can be found in the mass-radius relation and its dependence on the stellar metallicity. For a fixed mass, Keplerâ€™s law enforces the proportionality logâ¡Pâˆ3/2â¢logâ¡Aproportional-toğ‘ƒ32ğ´OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-A\log P\propto 3/2\,\log A. If the geometry of contact is the same irrespective of the chemical composition so that the relative sizes of components are independent of the metallicity, ri=Ri/Asubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğ´italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-Ar_{i}=R_{i}/A, then smaller stellar sizes Rğ‘…italic-RR should lead to smaller Ağ´italic-AA and to shorter orbital periods. Again, a qualification may be in order: The period changes may depend on metallicity in a much more complex way than just through simple radius scaling because the internal structure of PopulationÂ II contact binaries does not have to be identical to that of PopulationÂ I systems.

The mass-radius relation for low-metallicity stars is currently a subject of very lively discussions, stimulated by the distance determinations for subdwarfs, as provided by the Hipparcos mission. One of the most recent theoretical investigations of stellar models with varying abundances is by cas99 . The absolute magnitude calibration for stars with Teâ¢fâ¢f=5000subscriptğ‘‡ğ‘’ğ‘“ğ‘“5000italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-e italic-f italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:5000T_{eff}=5000Â K (Eq.Â (1) in this paper) can be re-written into a metallicity-radius dependence: Î”â¢logâ¡R=0.158â¢[Fâ¢e/H]+0.035â¢[Fâ¢e/H]2-0.485â¢Î”â¢YÎ”ğ‘…0.158delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»0.035superscriptdelimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»20.485Î”ğ‘ŒDelta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-R RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.158 OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.035 OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.485 Delta italic-Y\Delta\log R=0.158\,[Fe/H]+0.035\,[Fe/H]^{2}-0.485\Delta Y; with the solar abundance assumed to be ZâŠ™=0.0169subscriptğ‘direct-product0.0169italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.0169Z_{\odot}=0.0169 and [Fâ¢e/H]=logâ¡Z-logâ¡ZâŠ™delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»ğ‘subscriptğ‘direct-productOPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:equals OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-Z ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-Z POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:direct-product POSTSUBSCRIPT:end[Fe/H]=\log Z-\log Z_{\odot}. The size of the correction for helium abundance changes, Î”â¢YÎ”ğ‘ŒDelta italic-Y\Delta Y, which accompanies the metallicity changes as the stellar population ages, is a difficult matter. The authors discuss the large uncertainty in the ratio C=Î”â¢Y/Î”â¢Zğ¶Î”ğ‘ŒÎ”ğ‘italic-C RELOP:equals Delta italic-Y MULOP:divide Delta italic-ZC=\Delta Y/\Delta Z which is currently very poorly known; some observational results suggest C=3Â±2ğ¶plus-or-minus32italic-C RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:2C=3\pm 2 while the authors consider Câ‰ƒ5-6similar-to-or-equalsğ¶56italic-C RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:6C\simeq 5-6. The metallicity-radius relation is shown in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters for three values of Cğ¶italic-CC.

With the expected values of Î”â¢logâ¡Pâˆ3/2Ã—Î”â¢logâ¡Rproportional-toÎ”ğ‘ƒ32Î”ğ‘…Delta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P RELOP:proportional-to NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 MULOP:times Delta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-R\Delta\log P\propto 3/2\times\Delta\log R one can compute the expected variations of the absolute magnitude. We have a choice here: We can simply assume that the luminosity will scale with the square of the radius or we can use the logâ¡Pğ‘ƒOPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P\log P terms in the Equations 1 and 2. The former choice would suggest: Î”â¢MV=-5Ã—Î”â¢logâ¡RÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰5Î”ğ‘…Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 MULOP:times Delta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-R\Delta M_{V}=-5\times\Delta\log R, while the latter choice gives a steeper dependence: Î”â¢MV=-4.44Ã—3/2Ã—Î”â¢logâ¡RÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰4.4432Î”ğ‘…Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:4.44 MULOP:times NUMBER:3 MULOP:divide NUMBER:2 MULOP:times Delta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-R\Delta M_{V}=-4.44\times 3/2\times\Delta\log R (the period-term coefficients are basically identical for both color-index sets). In what follows, we will use the second expressions for consistency with the adopted expressions for MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal}, observing that the steepness of the period term (which probably hides many unaccounted period-dependent effects) may actually explain the unexpected absence of the [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] term in the equations giving MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal}.

The color-magnitude diagrams for the sample of the GC members are shown in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. The data plotted are the observed MVoâ¢bâ¢ssuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{obs} and the de-reddened color indices so that uncertainties with the metallicity corrections in MVcâ¢aâ¢lsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endM_{V}^{cal} do not enter directly into this figure (but only through the selection of cluster members, via the deviations Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V}). The Class-1 members, which we consider genuine members of the clusters, are marked by filled circles and the range of metallicity ([Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] smaller or larger than -1.51.5ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.5-1.5) is shown by the size of the symbol. The figure also contains the theoretical isochrones computed by the Padova group (ber94 ) for 14 Gyr and for three values of metallicity [Fâ¢e/H]=-1.66delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»1.66OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.66[Fe/H]=-1.66, -1.261.26ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.26-1.26 and -0.660.66ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.66-0.66. In addition, the data for members of old open cluster members are shown by small x-symbols, following the results in R98.

The most striking feature of the color-magnitude diagrams for PopulationÂ II contact binaries is the shift of the contact-binary sequence by about one magnitude below that for Galactic Disk systems. A similar shift is well known for single subdwarfs, but it is seen here for contact binaries for the first time. The sequence is relatively well defined and extends uniformly on both sides of the Turn-Off Point (TOP), similarly as in old open clusters such as CrÂ 261 (R98).

A group of Blue Stragglers (BS) in the low-metallicity clusters, to the blue of the TOP is the most conspicuous group of the contact binaries in the color-magnitude diagrams in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. A few Class-2 systems also have very blue color indices of the BS stars; since such systems practically do not occur among Disk contact systems we think that they are not foreground projections, but genuine cluster members with the Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} deviations larger than 0.5 mag. These systems are in the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set: V22 in NGCÂ 4372 and V8 in NGCÂ 6752; in the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set: V22 in NGCÂ 4372 and V65 in NGCÂ 5139. Thus, V22 in the controversial cluster NGCÂ 4372, with its Blue Stragglier characteristics, is intrinsically the brightest system in the current GC sample with MVoâ¢bâ¢s=1.83superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘œğ‘ğ‘ 1.83italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-o italic-b italic-s POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.83M_{V}^{obs}=1.83, (B-V)0=0.24subscriptğµğ‘‰00.24OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.24(B-V)_{0}=0.24 and (V-I)0=0.30subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼00.30OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.30(V-I)_{0}=0.30.

The period-color diagram is, to some degree, a more natural and precise way to display properties of contact binaries than the color-magnitude diagram. This is because one quantity, the orbital period, is known basically without error, at least when compared with photometric errors. Only one photometric quantity â€“ the color index â€“ then enters into the picture. The color index can still be affected by several factors, in addition to the measurement errors, the most severe being the uncertainty in the reddening correction, but the period-color relation is not affected by errors in the distance modulus.

FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters shows the two period-color diagrams for the GC sample, with the same symbols as in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. The reader is suggested to view both figures simultaneously and to note the common features. The figure contains the Short-Period Blue-Envelopes (SPBE) for Disk systems, shown as continuous lines for both color-index sets (open , ogle1 ). Their shapes are given by: (B-V)Sâ¢Pâ¢Bâ¢E=0.04â¢P-2.25subscriptğµğ‘‰ğ‘†ğ‘ƒğµğ¸0.04superscriptğ‘ƒ2.25OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-P italic-B italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.04 italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.25 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(B-V)_{SPBE}=0.04\,P^{-2.25} and (V-I)Sâ¢Pâ¢Bâ¢E=0.053â¢P-2.1subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼ğ‘†ğ‘ƒğµğ¸0.053superscriptğ‘ƒ2.1OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S italic-P italic-B italic-E POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.053 italic-P POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end(V-I)_{SPBE}=0.053\,P^{-2.1} (the orbital period Pğ‘ƒitalic-PP is in days). While the numerical values in these definitions do not have any physical meaning, the curves are important because they delineate location of the least-evolved contact systems in the Disk Population sample. As many theoretical investigations indicated, contact systems would normally evolve away from the main Sequence, toward larger stellar dimensions, longer orbital periods and cooler atmospheres. The interstellar reddening also increases the color index. Thus, the SPBE has a meaning of a Zero-Age Main Sequence for the Disk population systems.

The above considerations should also apply to PopulationÂ II contact systems except that, as pointed out by Webbink, the angular-momentum loss due to gravitation radiation emission may win over the long time scales involved and eventually lead to shortening of the orbital periods. As we see in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters, the GC systems indeed have periods shorter than those for Disk systems, but this is expected irrespective of whatever mechanism of forming them is involved: As discussed in SectionÂ 5, to be a contact system, a low-metallicity binary must have a short period because its components are small. Judging by the size and direction of the metallicity corrections (shown by arrows), the relatively larger effect is observed in Î”â¢logâ¡PÎ”ğ‘ƒDelta OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P\Delta\log P than in the color-index shifts Î”â¢(B-V)Î”ğµğ‘‰Delta OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)\Delta(B-V) and Î”â¢(V-I)Î”ğ‘‰ğ¼Delta OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)\Delta(V-I). Although the two changes can partly compensate each other in their control of the absolute magnitude, the compensation is not exact because the arrows in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters are not parallel to the lines of constant MVsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{V}. This was visible in the color-magnitude diagrams in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters, where the GC systems were obviously fainter than the Disk systems. It is striking how different PopulationÂ II contact systems are from the Galactic Disk systems, but also how similar they are within their group. Apparently, a difference in metallicity from the solar [Fâ¢e/H]â‰ƒ0similar-to-or-equalsdelimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»0OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:] RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0[Fe/H]\simeq 0 to -0.70.7ADDOP:minus NUMBER:0.7-0.7 or so produces a relatively larger change in their properties than a further change to -2.22.2ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2.2-2.2 observed for the most extreme-metallicity systems. Since most changes are due to the change in the component dimensions, this would argue for a relatively small value of the currently poorly-known coefficient C=Î”â¢Y/Î”â¢Zğ¶Î”ğ‘ŒÎ”ğ‘italic-C RELOP:equals Delta italic-Y MULOP:divide Delta italic-ZC=\Delta Y/\Delta Z (see FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters in SectionÂ 5).

The sample of binary stars considered in this paper contains six systems with EB-type light curves. Such light curves are characterized by unequally deep eclipses, but with strong variations between minima suggesting possibility of a physical contact. The OGLE sample (ogle2 ) contained only 2 systems of this type among 98 systems in a volume-limited sample of contact binaries selected using a Fourier light-curve shape filter. In this paper, we do not use this filter because it is sensitive to the phase coverage and tends to be too discriminatory. Thus, we assume that the six systems are related to contact systems. In fact, these may be various forms of semi-detached binaries in the pre-contact or broken-contact stages, with either the more massive, hotter or less-massive, cooler components filling their Roche lobes (egg96 ). The latter cases appear to be less common, but a good case of a very short period Algol has been recently identified in WÂ Crv (rl99 ).

Three among the six systems appear in the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set and three in the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set. Inspection of FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters and TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters shows that all but one are Class-1 cluster members; the one with a slightly larger Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} is a Class-2 member. Thus, they all follow the absolute-magnitude calibrations for normal contact binaries and seem to be genuine cluster members. This relatively high frequency of occurrence among contact systems, of 6 among 35 (or 39 if 4 Class-2 Blue Stragglers are added) is unexplained and interesting. We note that two among the six systems are Blue Stragglers.

section.h2: 9 Amplitude distribution and the Blue Stragglers

div.p: It has been noted in SectionÂ 6 that the contact system sequence continues without any obvious changes in the period, color or absolute magnitude properties across the Turn-Off Point, into the Blue Stragglers domain. Now we will address the only property which is available to characterize the light curves, the variability amplitude and its distribution.

The Blue Stragglers (BS) are an important group of stars in old stellar clusters. It is now recognized that they must form through binary evolution processes, although it appears that there are actually many such processes and it is not easy to find out which one occurs most commonly (leo96 , mat96b ). The BS formation and evolution is such a large and active area that special meetings have been devoted to it (saf93 ) and very active research continues. Contact BS are relatively easy to identify for several reasons: (1)Â They are bluer than typical galactic Disk systems which start appearing at (B-V)0<0.3subscriptğµğ‘‰00.3OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.3(B-V)_{0}<0.3 (R98), (2)Â Their photometry is relatively less difficult than for the Main Sequence stars because they are photometrically well above the level where â€“ usually formidable â€“ crowding problems for the MS stars set in. The question is: Are they in any other way different from the â€œnormalâ€ Main-Sequence contact systems in the GCâ€™s? One such property can be amplitudes of light variations. Although the amplitude statistics involves a convolution of the distribution of the mass-ratios with the distribution of orbital inclinations, as was discussed in ogle2 , lack of large amplitudes must mean that the large (qâ†’1â†’ğ‘1italic-q ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:1q\rightarrow 1, q=M2/M1â‰¤1ğ‘subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ‘€11italic-q RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:1q=M_{2}/M_{1}\leq 1) mass-ratios do not occur: When components differ in sizes, only small amplitudes are possible.

FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters shows the observed amplitudes for the GC members plotted in relation to the intrinsic color indices. For the color index values, we assume that systems with (B-V)0<0.4subscriptğµğ‘‰00.4OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.4(B-V)_{0}<0.4 or (V-I)0<0.55subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼00.55OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.55(V-I)_{0}<0.55 are Blue Stragglers. The amplitudes do show a change at the Turn-Off Point, but this change is well defined only for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set: The large amplitudes are observed only for the systems to the red of the TOP, that is for the genuine MS systems. The two-sided Kolmogorovâ€“Smirnov tests comparing distribution on both sides of the TOPâ€™s, limited to Class-1 systems, indicates that the difference in the distributions is not significant for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set, but the probability of a random chance producing the observed difference for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set is only 1.1Ã—10-51.1superscript105NUMBER:1.1 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end1.1\times 10^{-5}. The significance changes only slightly when Class-2 members are added with the probabilities of a random result of 0.05 for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set and 0.71Ã—10-50.71superscript105NUMBER:0.71 MULOP:times NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end0.71\times 10^{-5} for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set. The change in the observed amplitude distribution at the TOP is therefore very highly significant for the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set, but insignificant for the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set. At this moment, we have no explanation for this difference between the color-index sets except that â€“ as pointed several times in this paper â€“ it may be related to the photometric difficulties in the Bğµitalic-BB-band for red stars and to the larger and more uncertain reddening corrections in the (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) color index.

On the basis of the above numbers one would be tempted to claim that, indeed, the BSâ€™s have smaller amplitudes than the Main-Sequence contact systems. However, a caution is in order here: It is very important that we do not see small amplitudes among the Main Sequence systems below the TOP, only the large ones. They are obviously missing there because for random orbital inclinations systems showing small amplitudes should be always more common than systems showing large amplitudes. The histograms in the upper parts of the panels of FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters contain the expected amplitude distributions calculated in ogle2 for two assumptions of the mass-ratio distribution, a flat Qâ¢(q)ğ‘„ğ‘italic-Q OPEN:( italic-q CLOSE:)Q(q) and Qâ¢(q)=(1-q)ğ‘„ğ‘1ğ‘italic-Q OPEN:( italic-q CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-q CLOSE:)Q(q)=(1-q). The data for the Disk systems in the OGLE sample suggested that the distribution may be actually even more strongly decaying with qâ†’1â†’ğ‘1italic-q ARROW:rightarrow NUMBER:1q\rightarrow 1 than the one âˆ(1-q)proportional-toabsent1ğ‘RELOP:proportional-to OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-q CLOSE:)\propto(1-q), because large amplitudes are exceedingly rare in an unbiased sample (this is very much unlike the sky-field sample). In the case of the present GC sample, a comparison of the theoretical distributions with the observed ones suggests that the observed data may be severely modified by strong detection selection effects for systems below the TOP. While almost all systems in the BS group appear to be detected (there is only a small depression in the distribution for Aâ¢mâ¢pâ¢lV<0.2ğ´ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘‰0.2italic-A italic-m italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.2Ampl_{V}<0.2), the MS systems appear to be entirely missed for Aâ¢mâ¢pâ¢lV<0.3ğ´ğ‘šğ‘subscriptğ‘™ğ‘‰0.3italic-A italic-m italic-p italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.3Ampl_{V}<0.3 due to the difficulties with accurate photometry in conditions where measurement errors and crowding problems rapidly increase with the apparent magnitude.

section.h2: 10 Frequency of WÂ UMa-type systems in globular clusters

div.p: The discovery selection effect described in the previous section may lead to an under-estimate of the number of the contact Main Sequence (below TOP) systems by a factor of the order of about 5 to 10. The previous results for the sky-field sample should be recalled here as a sobering experience: For several years the frequency of contact binaries of one per one thousand MS stars has been considered a well-established, â€œtextbook-levelâ€ fact, in spite of the warnings that the sky sample of known contact binaries contained only large-amplitude systems (see FigureÂ 2 in kr94 ). Only the systematic characteristics of the OGLE sample (R98) have shown that the apparent111We distinguish the apparent frequency, which is uncorrected for missed low-inclination systems, from the spatial frequency which is about 1.5 to 2 times higher. The correction factor depends on the mass-ratio distribution (ogle2 ). frequency is about ten times higher, reaching about 100 â€“ 130 normal Fâ€“K dwarfs per one contact system. A very similar situation re-emerges here, except that this time we can directly suspect â€“ from the difference in the amplitude distributions on both sides of the TOP â€“ that the discovery selection effects are more severe below the TOP. We cannot correct for these selection effects because they must be different for each cluster and are very difficult to quantify.

In this situation, it has been felt prudent to abandon attempts of determining the frequency below the TOP and concentrate on the frequency data for the BS systems. This is in turn complicated by lack of information in discovery papers on the number of Blue Stragglers which were monitored for variability. A simple, but potentially risky assumption has been made at that point that the numbers of the BSâ€™s shown in diagrams in the discovery papers are equal to the numbers of systems which were actually monitored. Frequently stars without measurable color indices (and not shown in color-magnitude diagrams) are monitored for variability, but one may hope that this would not happen in the BS region. Thus, approximate numbers of the Blue Stragglers, NBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘ğµğ‘†italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{BS}, have been estimated by simply counting of data points on the color-magnitude diagrams. It is stressed that these are very approximate estimates; for example, for Ï‰ğœ”italic-omega\omega Cen the available estimate for the fields Dâ€“F (kal97b ) was multiplied by two to obtain the total number in all observed fields. For 47Â Tuc (kal98b ) unpublished data have been supplied by Dr.Â KaÅ‚uÅ¼ny. The estimates are given in TableÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters and should be compared with the number of the contact BS systems, nBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘›ğµğ‘†italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{BS}. In doing so we immediately see the problem of numerically very small values for nBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘›ğµğ‘†italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{BS} which are obviously subject to relatively large Poissonian fluctuations. Thus, we can see that we are still very far from being able to correlate the frequency of contact BS systems with cluster properties such as the metallicity index, [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H], or the concentration parameter, cğ‘italic-cc. In this situation another disputable step was made in assuming that the average frequency is the same for all GCâ€™s. This can be derived by simply summing NBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘ğµğ‘†italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{BS} and nBâ¢Ssubscriptğ‘›ğµğ‘†italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:endn_{BS} for all clusters and taking their ratio. The result is that 20 contact binaries are observed among about 900 Blue Stragglers. Thus the average inverse frequency is fBâ¢S=45Â±10subscriptğ‘“ğµğ‘†plus-or-minus4510italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:45 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:10f_{BS}=45\pm 10 normal BS stars per one contact system. This frequency is the apparent one, that is it applies to systems which can be discovered, without any corrections for systems missed because of the low orbital inclinations. Since we do not know the mass-ratio distribution for the contact BS systems, we cannot correct for these missed systems to evaluate the true spatial frequency.

The inverse apparent frequency of fBâ¢S=45subscriptğ‘“ğµğ‘†45italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:45f_{BS}=45 is significantly different from the one observed for the Disk stars, which is approximately fDâ¢iâ¢sâ¢kâ‰ƒ100-130similar-to-or-equalssubscriptğ‘“ğ·ğ‘–ğ‘ ğ‘˜100130italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-D italic-i italic-s italic-k POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:100 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:130f_{Disk}\simeq 100-130. Thus, the Blue Straggler population of the globular clusters contains some 2-323NUMBER:2 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:32-3 times more contact binaries than the Old Disk stars. We note also that the inverse frequency at the level of 45Â±10plus-or-minus4510NUMBER:45 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1045\pm 10 is in perfect accord with lack of detections in clusters poor in Blue Stragglers where their absence can be simply explained by the Poisson fluctuations.

The high frequency of contact binaries among Blue Stragglers is visible in the color index and period distributions shown in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters. These distributions are obviously far from being rigorous in the statistical sense, yet they do show interesting trends. When compared with the Disk systems (R98), the GC contact binaries occupy only the blue ends of the (B-V)0subscriptğµğ‘‰0OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(B-V)_{0} and (V-I)0subscriptğ‘‰ğ¼0OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end(V-I)_{0} distributions. Note, however, that the blue end points are the approximately same for the GC and Disk sample distributions indicating that the Disk sample may contain an admixture of low-metallicity objects similar to those in globular clusters. While the red systems are mostly likely under-represented in the GC sample because of the selection biases against faint, red systems, we see a definite lack of long-period systems which are intrinsically the brightest and should be easily detected. Of course temporal-window biases for the GC sample may have contributed here (in the sense that monitoring programs were by necessity short), especially when compared with the excellent data for the 5 kpc OGLE sample (R98) which defines the long-period part of the period distribution in FigureÂ WÂ UMa-type Binary Stars in Globular Clusters.

Although at least 1/3 among 86 systems presumably located in the analyzed globular clusters are foreground projections from the Disk which must be carefully weeded out, we can state with confidence that contact binaries in globular clusters are definitely different than the very common Disk population systems. The main feature are their short orbital periods resulting from small dimensions of components. This is seen not only in the distribution of the orbital periods, but also in low luminosities. Thus, the downward shift of the contact binary subdwarf sequence below that for the Disk systems is primarily due to the reduced-dimension effect, not to the blue shift caused by the reduced blanketing. The long-period systems are intrinsically more luminous and easier to discover so that their absence is highly significant.

While the metallicity effects are clearly seen in the properties of the PopulationÂ II contact binaries, to our surprise, they are not visible in the MVcâ¢aâ¢l=MVcâ¢aâ¢lâ¢(logâ¡P,câ¢oâ¢lâ¢oâ¢r)superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™superscriptsubscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘œğ‘™ğ‘œğ‘Ÿitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-a italic-l POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P PUNCT:, italic-c italic-o italic-l italic-o italic-r CLOSE:)M_{V}^{cal}=M_{V}^{cal}(\log P,color) calibrations. More exactly, they do not manifest themselves in the calibration based on the (V-I)ğ‘‰ğ¼OPEN:( italic-V ADDOP:minus italic-I CLOSE:)(V-I) color index; the data utilizing the (B-V)ğµğ‘‰OPEN:( italic-B ADDOP:minus italic-V CLOSE:)(B-V) color index are too poor to be sure that the calibration does not need a metallicity term. For simplicity, we assumed that both calibrations (which are used only to select the systems, not to analyze them) do not require any [Fâ¢e/H]delimited-[]ğ¹ğ‘’ğ»OPEN:[ italic-F italic-e MULOP:divide italic-H CLOSE:][Fe/H] dependent terms. It is recommended that the Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI bandpass filter combination be used in the future because the Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV data may indeed show some metallicity dependence, but â€“ more importantly â€“ are more susceptible to photometric errors for red stars and to reddening correction uncertainties.

Very little can be said about contact binaries located on the Main Sequence, below the Turn-Off Point (TOP). Severe discovery selection effects are suspected from the peculiar distribution of amplitudes with missing small amplitudes. In contrast, 20 Blue Straggler contact binaries known at this time give a reasonable estimate of their frequency of occurrence of one such system (counted as one object) per 45Â±10plus-or-minus4510NUMBER:45 ADDOP:plus-or-minus NUMBER:1045\pm 10 Blue Stragglers. This reciprocal apparent frequency is about 2â€“3 times higher than for the Disk systems among the normal Fâ€“K stars. It is entirely possible that the same mechanism which produces a continuous sequence of contact binaries across the TOP in old open clusters simply had more time to produce more contact systems in globular clusters.

div.p: Captions to figures:

figure.p: The absolute-magnitude deviations Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V} are shown here for both data-sets (Bâ¢Vğµğ‘‰italic-B italic-VBV set in the upper panels, Vâ¢Iğ‘‰ğ¼italic-V italic-IVI set in the lower panels), versus the respective colour indices and logâ¡Pğ‘ƒOPFUNCTION:logarithm italic-P\log P (in days). Note the large fraction of foreground systems with negative values of Î”â¢MVÎ”subscriptğ‘€ğ‘‰Delta italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-V POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\Delta M_{V}. Amplitudes of light variations for both color-index data-sets are shown in relation to de-reddened color indices. The vertical broken lines delineate the regions of Blue Stragglers. The data with crosses superimposed on the circles (closed for Class-1 and open for Class-2 members) mark the EB-type systems. Since their primary eclipses are deeper than for normal contact systems, they have â€“ on the average â€“ larger amplitudes than typical contact system.

The color-index distributions for Class-1 members (continuous line histograms) with added Class-2 members (broken line histograms) are compared with Disk systems from the Baadeâ€™s Window OGLE sample (R98) (shaded area). Note that while the OGLE data come from a volume-limited samples (3 kpc, with modifications at the long-period end from the 5 kpc sample), the GC sample most probably contains many detection-selection biases. The OGLE sample data are shown here with arbitrary normalization, only to indicate the shapes of the distributions.
